texts.definition: Narration structures in games which allow players or spectators to know more than any individual diegetic person.
markups: <style="Definition">Narration structures in games which allow players or spectators to know more than any individual diegetic person.</style>

Some games allow a player to know more about the game world and events than the characters he or she plays. This pattern is call <style="CurrentLink">Melodramatic Structures</style> in this collection. The idea for the pattern (and <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style> comes from Lankoski<ref name="Lankoski2010"/>. Here, a distinction by Smith<ref name="Smith"/> between detective narration and melodramatic narration is used to form gameplay design patterns. In Smith's terms, detective narration restricts readers' knowledge to that of a protagonist while in melodramatic narration readers' knows more than any single character.

In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fahrenheit">Fahrenheit</link></style> the player switches between characters played, thereby getting a more detailed understanding on the unfolding narration than any individual character in the game has.

Three concrete design patterns exist to create <style="CurrentLink">Melodramatic Structures</style>. <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> allows a game to switch between <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and therefore give more information to the player than a single <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="summary-updates">Summary Updates</link></style> can explain what happens before, between, or after <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> so that players have the right understanding of the reasons and consequences of events in a <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scene</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Voice-overs">Voice-overs</link></style> can add explanations to the events that are occurring which the players get but not the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. Per their definitions, <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style> and <style="CurrentLink">Melodramatic Structures</style> are incompatible.

<style="CurrentLink">Melodramatic Structures</style> can be used in both <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. In fact, due to the fact that <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> typically present different view points of the game to different players ''through'' <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> these types of games nearly always have <style="CurrentLink">Melodramatic Structures</style> of sorts. This does however not in itself affect narration significantly since <style="CurrentLink">Melodramatic Structures</style> often require significant shifts in perspective for individual players to have their intended effects. This typically means that they are easier to plan for in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, e.g. by switching <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> are changed (see <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fahrenheit">Fahrenheit</link></style> for an example of this).

While <style="Link"><link="god-views">God Views</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="third-person-views">Third-Person Views</link></style> may show players more of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> than a single <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatar</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> may see, this typically does not provide more than ephemeral differences in what a player and a <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> knows.

<style="CurrentLink">Melodramatic Structures</style> is one way to modulate <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> is a game. While they do use <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, they do not change how these can perform gameplay actions.
